text: @AlexWisnerArt @EsemicolonR @Nath_eRecycLbin @stone_toss True. But a person using AI to generate images does not look to control the shape and width of individual lines. Same as other experimental or non-standard tools or methods -- think Pollock. This is why I don't think it's a good argument. Lack of soul, art theft are better ones.

I’ve decided I’m gonna keep my account public — I’ve explained this on my alt, but I feel that if my art is going to be fed into AI, then it already has.
Other platforms don’t have great regulation on preventing art theft for AI training either, Twitter just has an AI of its own.
ai art *is* art theft in most cases, but if your company can already steal art regularly and get away with it, what difference does using an ai model to steal art make?

RT @ZedEdge: On the topic of #AIart: a common defense for AI is that it learns from other art in the same way humans do, therefore it's not…

@Okchibi5 I posted this guy before, he's making over 500$ a month on patreon reposting Doppel, Catco_Art, and a bunch of other small jp artist, and selling the art in sets on the patreon, while also using AI as well for other sets. Literal art theft.

@tobito420 No, it's not "literal theft" because an ai produced image is not the same as the work it takes in. You can't copyright an art style. Ai is no different from humans in this aspect. 

It being a threat to jobs is the only argument that actually holds intellectual weight, really.
the way that we talk about AI art is so broken. idgaf that it's 'soulless.' i'm not trying to prove the existence of the human soul, i'm against art theft and the destruction of the environment

@doubleyoorizz Put another way, if the AI is going to continue, what use is there in stopping your own work? Fact is, traces and art theft have been easy to do since digital art became a thing. 

Even today some shows steal animation bits from other shows to speed up their own production.

(2/7)
People love calling AI art “theft,” but that argument falls flat. Artists have ALWAYS built on what came before them. From photographers using pre-made filters to designers borrowing fonts. AI does the same thing—takes publicly available data and mixes it up. Where’s the… https://t.co/jNH4rn2PDl https://t.co/YMF4LT7YSN

@MrTooty2 @tangewrione @HaareBlond @Se7enTheo @naegiko @whynesspower The dataset has to pull data from somewhere. Remember, AI cannot create original content. Its all just a rendition of the data it's been fed. So, it is absolutely true that AI art can be considered theft.

Making another side comment - AI can do INCREDIBLE things. Especially regarding coding and predicting using statistics. WITH human guidance. But passing unfiltered images and text as reality is dangerous. Others have said plenty on surface-level (but legitimate) art theft.

@RadLordLewd @Milkmeray Theft is the act of depriving another of access to their property.  As I already explained, training AI on another's artwork does not deprive them of access to said artwork.  So, no, this is not theft.  How do you think humans learn to produce art?  We also reference artwork.
I don't think posting AI slop and art theft is a "let him have fun" thing. https://t.co/cqtj6JybOY

@Milkmeray You're essentially promoting AI as something legitimate rather than calling it out for what it is. Lazy art theft. You're celebrating and drawing attention to something that is inherently unethical.
@urnotmyrealmom @keshaorder Ai art is theft from real artists! Look how ai even works girl

@cozmicanomaly @MukiEX57 @SaltyTGP @SayuriArtsy AI art is the result of an individual expressing their imagination through skilled use of generative software.  This makes it a form of art by definition.  As for your claim of theft, you are incorrect.  Training AI on another's art does not deprive them of access to said art.
@MukiEX57 @SaltyTGP @SayuriArtsy Ai "art" isn't art. It's theft.
